awd_titl_txt: Undergraduate Service Learning Experiences with Data: Mathematics in the Community
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims to serve the national interest by transforming how undergraduate students engage with and learn mathematics in a new first-year general education (GenEd) course. In this course students will analyze and create visualizations of data in order to answer authentic questions from non-profit community partners. By developing data literacy and visualization skills critical in an information-dense society, students will meet general education requirements in quantitative literacy. Researchers expect that students will increase in confidence and interest in mathematics and data science. Meaningful interactions with community partners will enable students to develop an increased commitment to community engagement and enhanced workforce skills, such as: leadership, communication, and critical thinking skills. The course is also expected to engage students who may have lower interest and self-efficacy in mathematics, thus broadening participation in data science.

The project aims to increase understanding of the effectiveness and feasibility of service learning as a context to improve student outcomes in GenEd mathematics courses. Service learning is a method of engaged teaching and learning that emphasizes critical thinking and problem solving by connecting course content with real-world experiences. Through inquiry-based learning the project will engage students in authentic inquiry, solving real-world problems and documenting learning through regular reflection. The project will investigate the educational impact of the GenEd course in terms of students’ interest and engagement in mathematics and other STEM disciplines. Retention in the university and future course-taking behavior will also be examined. A within-subject design will be used to measure how the course changes student attitudes towards STEM by having students complete a pre-course survey and a corresponding post-course survey using validated measures of self-efficacy, interest, and STEM attitudes. In addition, the research team will work with instructors of other GenEd mathematics courses to implement a between-subject design to compare courses. Comparisons will look both at absolute outcomes (e.g. comparing interest in future STEM-course taking at the end of the semester between each course) and also at changes from the beginning to the end of the semester (e.g. gains in mathematical self-efficacy). The team will apply a mixed-methods approach that uses quantitative data to measure progress towards participation targets and qualitative data that provides insights into the research questions as well as insights into the successes and challenges of the overall project. Data collection will consist of semi-structured interviews and focus groups, project documents, reflections, classroom observations, surveys, and university enrollment data. Project results and deliverables will be shared with other institutions through a public website as well as publications. The NSF IUSE: EHR Program supports research and development projects to improve the effectiveness of STEM education for all students. Through the Engaged Student Learning track, the program supports the creation, exploration, and implementation of promising practices and tools.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The USLED project successfully created STAT 1100: Data Literacy and Visualization, a service learning course which fulfills the university’s general education quantitative literacy requirement. Students learn basic data organization, manipulation, and visualization techniques using industry standard software tools (Excel and Tableau). They apply their knowledge and skills by partnering with community organizations to answer authentic questions with data. In lieu of a final exam, at the end of each semester, students present the results of their strategic decision making and forecasting analysis to the partner organizations in a session open to the public. STAT 1100 was successful in demonstrating that service learning can be used in a general education mathematics course. We successfully disseminated this idea to multiple communities including mathematics, community engagement, and education conferences. We have worked with several institution who expressed interest in implementing STAT 1100 in their own settings.

STAT 1100 has the highest pass rate of all general education math courses at UNO, with an 82% rate of students achieving grades of A, B, or C. Project partners have included health-related organizations, the Strategic Air Command and Aerospace Museum, and organizations that address homelessness and the generational cycle of incarceration. In one project, Keep Omaha Beautiful asked students to identify the best non-buildable vacant lots to be considered for mini-arboretums. The students used geospatial locations of vacant lots, city parks, local tree canopies, and land slopes to compile a list of lots to consider, then identified other criteria such as poverty to make recommendations. In another project, students analyzed the administration of COVID-19 assistance for rent/mortgage, auto, and utility payments. As shown in the attached figure, which students created and shared with the Metro Area Continuum of Care for the Homeless (MAACH) during their final presentation, payments were equitably distributed in nearly all cases.

Students in the course reported high satisfaction, particularly as compared to other math courses. Both mathematical self-efficacy and interest in math show strongly significant growth (p < .001). In post-course focus groups and reflections, students reported that the assignments were useful because it “didn’t feel like we learned things and then never had to use them again.” They also noted that the final projects are a “real life experience” that is “good experience for the workplace.” Reflecting the literature on community engaged courses, students appreciated the opportunity to add value to organizations whose missions they find meaningful. One student valued “knowing [the local nature preserve] are conservation and they can’t afford a data scientist.” More generally, one student joyfully exclaimed, “I’m helping someone!” 

The supporting image of a poster shows examples of a diversity of student projects and project outcomes.


Last Modified: 02/20/2025
Modified by: Michelle Friend
